articles.title: MAY 1987
articles.summary: This document details the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) schedule of events for May and June 1987. Highlights include the Seventh Annual Astronomical Auction, several field expeditions to Fremont Peak, and the Grand Opening Night for the Fremont Peak Observatory Association. The calendar also lists board meetings, astronomy classes, an indoor star party, and a general meeting on UFOs.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article announces two upcoming events: the Seventh Annual Astronomical Auction on May 2nd, which will replace the monthly General Meeting, and the Grand Opening of the new 30-inch observatory on May 30th. The Grand Opening will feature guest speakers, slide shows, and an evening of observing, inviting everyone to attend.

articles.title: JUNE 27TH DATE SET FOR ANNUAL SJAA PICNIC
articles.summary: The annual SJAA picnic is scheduled for June 27th at Grant Ranch County Park, starting around noon. The event will utilize the picnic and Bar-B-Q facilities located north of the parking lot previously used for star parties. Further information and directions will be provided in next month's announcement.

articles.title: DR. CLYDE TOMBAUGH TO SPEAK AT 1987 RTMC
articles.summary: The article announces the 19th Annual Riverside Telescope Makers Conference (RTMC) in May 1987, highlighting Dr. Clyde Tombaugh as a special guest speaker, along with details on location, dates, and awards. It also provides a detailed evaluation of the new 20mm Nagler Type-2 eyepiece, praising its optical performance for deep-sky observation and coma correction, while noting its large size, short exit pupil distance, and high price.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS BY: JAY REYNOLDS FREEMAN
articles.summary: Jay Reynolds Freeman reviews "The Night Sky," a compact 1985 star atlas by Wil Tirion and Ian Ridpath. He highly recommends this 8x12 cm softcover guide for its comprehensive charts, detailed object descriptions suitable for small telescopes, durable build, and affordable price. The atlas is praised for its utility as an observing aid for star parties, finderscopes, and binoculars, despite its modest magnitude limit.

articles.title: SCIENTISTS IDENTIFY STAR THAT BECAME SUPERNOVA BY: DAVID L. CHANDLER
articles.summary: Astronomers have confirmed the identification of Sanduleak-62 202, a blue supergiant star, as the progenitor for Supernova 1987a in the Large Magellanic Cloud, marking the first time a star has been visually recorded before exploding. Despite initial confusion and dismissal, its confirmation provides invaluable data for understanding supernovae. However, the identified star type and the supernova's unexpected increasing brightness continue to challenge existing theoretical models.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHOLZ
articles.summary: This article, titled "Comet Comments," provides updates on several comets visible in the evening and morning skies. Comet Wilson is entering the evening sky, while Halley's Comet continues to fade, and two other comets are visible in the morning. Additionally, Periodic Comet Klemola has been recovered, and a new faint comet, Comet Torres, has been discovered.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This document provides detailed ephemerides and observing notes for three comets: Comet Sorrells (1986n), Comet Nishikawa-Takamizawa-Tago (1987c), and Comet Wilson (1986L). It includes tables with celestial coordinates (Right Ascension, Declination), elongation, and magnitude for dates spanning late April through early June. Accompanying notes describe each comet's distance, apparent motion, brightness trends, and ideal observing periods or locations in the sky.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Halley (1982i)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Halley (1982i) from late April to early June, detailing its celestial coordinates, elongation, and apparent magnitude. It notes that the comet is currently a faint object, visible only with large telescopes, and describes its apparent motion relative to Earth. Instructions for converting to J2000 coordinates are also included.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article details the naming conventions for newly discovered comets, which are typically named after their discoverer(s). It explains rules for multiple discoverers, visual versus photographic discoveries, and the special cases of recovering lost periodic comets. The text also touches on how communication speeds have historically influenced co-discovery opportunities and provides statistics on multi-named comets since 1975.

articles.title: SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE BY: BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: NASA and the White House have agreed to a scaled-back space station program, delaying the start of construction for phase one to 1994 with permanent manning by 1996. The second phase of the station's development, including elements like keels and experiment booms, has been indefinitely deferred. The initial phase will comprise a main truss, U.S. lab, living quarters, a polar orbiting platform, and modules from Europe, Japan, and Canada.

articles.title: NASA SHOVED OUT OF THE LAUNCH BUSINESS
articles.summary: Multiple government agencies are taking steps to diminish NASA's role in the launch business. The Secretary of Transportation is pushing NASA to procure commercial expendable boosters for most payloads, while the Commerce Department will directly contract the private sector for ELV launches, bypassing NASA. Furthermore, the Air Force has decided to exclude NASA from the development of the Heavy-Lift Launch Vehicle.

articles.title: SOVIET SHUTTLE PROGRAM IS MAKING BROAD PROGRESS
articles.summary: The Soviet Union is making significant progress on its shuttle program, having conducted a flight readiness firing of its heavy lift booster, which is expected to have its first unmanned flight by mid-summer and a manned shuttle flight by late 1987 or early 1988. Concurrently, their small manned spaceplane vehicle is nearing full-scale manned flight testing, following successful orbital flights of a 1/4 scale model and recent successes of its SL-16 booster.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS AND INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) hosts monthly General Meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" at the Los Gatos Red Cross building on the 1st Saturday of each month. These events provide a friendly atmosphere for members to share their astronomical interests, including astrophotography, deep sky observation, and telescope making, often featuring shared telescopes or slide shows. The SJAA also holds board meetings and an introductory astronomy workshop during these gatherings.

articles.title: OFFICERS
articles.summary: This document lists the current officers of an organization, including their positions such as President, Vice-President, Secretary, Treasurer, and Editor. For each officer, their full name and contact phone number are provided.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS
articles.summary: This document presents a list of names and corresponding phone numbers for the individuals serving on the Board of Directors. It primarily serves as a contact directory for the organization's leadership.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It details different membership tiers, including "Membership Only," "Membership/S&T," and "Junior (Under 18)," along with their corresponding fees. Applicants are required to provide personal contact information and can submit the completed form at an SJAA meeting or by mail to the Treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document is an optional questionnaire designed to gather information about an individual's astronomical interests, whether they own a telescope, and areas where they feel qualified to assist others. It appears to be part of a mailing from an organization (likely SJAA, given the address) and is marked as 'NEWS MATERIAL' and 'TIME VALUE â€” DATED'.
